comment._content: At the time, there were two William Kissam Vanderbilts. The father was born in 1849 and died in 1920. At the time of WWI he was married to his second wife, the former Miss Anne Harriman, who had previously been widowed twice. The son, by WKV's first wife, was born in 1878 and died in 1944. He married Virginia Graham Fair in 1899; they separated after ten years and were divorced in 1927. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Kissam_Vanderbilt en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Kissam_Vanderbilt_II

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Following the Anne Harriman track, I find www.faubourgmontmartre.com/grannyww1.html which confirms that the older Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt (and her husband) were active in war relief for the French, and in hospital work in particular. I find plenty of evidence that she worked in the American Ambulance Hospital in Neuilly (which was established in a large school building), but so far nothing to indicate that she turned her home into a hospital. There is no indication that the younger Mrs. Vanderbilt ( en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Fair_Vanderbilt ) was involved in the same sort of activities, although she did have Paris connections.
